dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young family together in bed.  It is a bright summer morning.  Father, mother, and a three year old girl are still asleep.  They are naked.  A light breeze drifts int the room.  The scene is serene and softly suspended. Head credits appear over this idyllic image.  The little girl turns in her sleep.  A dog barks outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the peaceful tableau of the sleeping family, the sce shifts to a vehicle entering a car wash.  The image is sh through the windshield, from the driver's point of view. The car enters the lathered world of spinning felt wheels and gushing water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the car MITCHELL STEPHENS, a man in his mid-fiftie listens to a stirring piece of music.  The sound of the c wash is filtered out by the strains of music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone booth is located in a rundown area of a large city.  A young woman, ZOE, enters the booth and lifts the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MITCHELL STEPHENS is going through the wash.  The automat mops and buffers embrace his car with water and suds.  Th cellular phone in the car rings.  MITCHELL picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?  Yes, I'll accept the charges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZOE is on the phone.  There's a figure outside the booth waiting for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, it's me...How are you doing? That's great...Where are you? What's that sound?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MITCHELL in his car, playing with the volume on his radio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in a car wash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car wash!  Wow, I've never talked to you when you've been in a car wash.  Make sure you've got the windows closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember that time we were having the car washed and I started playing with the automatic window?  How old was I, Daddy?  Five or six?  I got absolutely soaked, remember? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you calling me, Zoe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why am I calling you?  You're my father.  I'm not supposed to call you?  What's the matter with wanting to talk to you, Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing's wrong with trying to talk to me, Zoe. ZOE (over the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's the problem? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The problem is I have no idea who I'm talking to right now. ZOE (over the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause you think I'm stoned, Daddy? 'Cause you think I've got a needle stuck in my arm?  Is that what you're thinking, Daddy? Pause.  MITCHELL doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you wondering if I scored, Daddy, and I'm calling you for money?  That I'm begging?  God, I don't fucking believe it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MITCHELL is emotionally stunned by ZOE'S voice.  She is heard over the phone. ZOE (over the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy!  Are you listening to me, Daddy?! The music that MITCHELL has been listening to becomes lou as he stares at the spinning felt wheels of the car wash. ZOE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: DADDY
dialogues.text: MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't you talk to me? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I...I just need to know what state you're in so I know...how to talk to you...how to act... MITCHELL is in pain.  He closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone booth is deserted.  ZOE is nowhere to be seen. Over this image, the sounds of a band playing a blues number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blues number continues as the camera cranes down to t bandstand of a country fair.  A local band is rehearsing. Around the practising band, various carpenters and technicians are making final preparations for that evenin big event. One of the people watching the band is SAM BURNELL, a man his early forties.  He watches his daughter, NICOLE, as s sings into the microphone.  NICOLE is sixteen. NICOLE stares at her father as she sings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAM looking back at his daughter.  He is intensely proud her.  SAM is a carpenter, working on at the fair site.  H gets back to his work, hammering a supporting beam into t grandstand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP of a three year old girl, staring up into the le Her face is full of sweetness and trust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MITCHELL STEPHENS in a crowded airport washroom, watching young father, PETER, trying to change the diaper on his three year old daughter. MITCHELL stares at the little girl, his face registering wistful smile.  PETER is having a hard time trying to fin the towel from the toddler's bag and keeping an eye on he at the same time. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Need a hand? PETER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, it you could find a towel in this bag.  I know my wife packed one in there... MITCHELL comes forward and searches through the toddler's bag. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always think you're prepared for these things. PETER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about it. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old is she? PETER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost three. MITCHELL (finding a towel)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this it? PETER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfect. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we go. PETER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. PETER lays the towel across the counter, and dries the little girl.  MITCHELL watches as PETER puts a new diaper her.  The toddler stares up at MITCHELL, her eyes are playful. MITCHELL stares at the girl's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME CUT back to MITCHELL honking the horn of his car, trying to get someone's attention.  No response.  MITCHEL picks up his cell phone, and dials the operator. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, operator, I'm in a strange situation.  I'm calling from my car, and I appear to be stuck in a car wash...A car wash, yes...Is there anyway you could...Hello?...Hello?... The line has died. MITCHELL searches for an umbrella, finds one, and tries t get out of the car without getting soaked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MITCHELL as he leaves the car, trying to protect himself from the onslaught of water with his umbrella.  He is immediately soaked by a large mop.  The camera watches MITCHELL as he makes his way towards light at the end of wash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MITCHELL walks into the office of the car wash.  No one i there.  There is an ominous buzz coming from another room MITCHELL moves towards the garage of the car wash/auto repair establishment.  He moves into a larger room, full discarded auto parts.  The buzzing noise is coming from a electric guitar, which has been left on, and is on the ve of screeching feedback. Someone was just here.  They are nowhere to be seen. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? No response.  MITCHELL picks up the guitar, which begins produce a terrifying electronic feedback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAM and NICOLE wander through the fairground.  Various ri and concession stands are being set up.  SAM has his arm around NICOLE. SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was great. NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to blow everyone away. NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean it? SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't sound like one hundred percent absolutely sure. SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am.  Really.  It was awesome. NICOLE assesses SAM.  Sensing his sincerity, she throws h arms around him in a gesture of unabashed excitement. NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so happy, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MITCHELL STEPHEN'S car pulls into the parking lot of this run-down roadside motel.  In the fading light, a magnific mountain range is seen in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MITCHELL enters the reception area, and rings a bell on t desk.  After a few moments RISA WALKER appears.  She is a exhausted looking woman in her mid-thirties, once attract but very run-down.  RISA stares at MITCHELL'S soaked clothes. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it raining outside? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I...had an accident. Pause.  RISA stares at MITCHELL, her expression somewhere else. MITCHELL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a room? RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you be spending more than a night? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard to say.  I might have...some business here. A voice is heard from the darkness beyond the desk. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a reporter? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. WENDELL WALKER, RISA'S husband, appears from the darkness WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You here about the accident? MITCHELL stares at WENDELL'S haunted eyes, then looks bac at RISA.  He immediately knows their story. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  I'm a lawyer.  I realize this is an awful time, but it's important that we talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of men are setting up the ferris wheel for the country fair.  SAM and NICOLE walk into the shot, eating cream cones.  SAM waves at someone he recognizes in the distance. SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's sit down. NICOLE nods, her mind elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAM and NICOLE are sitting at an outside table, finishing their cones. A school bus pulls up into the fairground.  NICOLE watche as young children spill out of the bus and gather outside NICOLE smiles at this scene.  SAM notices, turns around t see the children, then turns back to NICOLE. SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's so funny? NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just the way Dolores gets so excited about bringing the kids to check out the animals.  It's like the biggest thing in her life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOLORES DRISCOLL, a warm and cheery woman in her forties, leading the young children into the large exhibition barn the fair site. DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, kids.  I want you all to listen to me.  Rule number one  No one is allowed to stick their fingers into the cages.  I don't care how cute some of these animals may be, the fact is they don't like being here, no matter how many ribbons some of them have won...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MITCHELL STEPHENS is having a meeting with WENDELL and RI WALKER in their livingroom behind the reception area. MITCHELL has a pad of paper and is taking notes. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kyle Lambston's a drunk.  Nobody likes him.  He's a nasty piece of work. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In what way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been drinking since high school. Fucked himself up.  Used to be smart enough. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any criminal record? WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably half a dozen traffic convictions.  Drunk driving.  Lost his licence.  That's why he don't work no more. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't get off that shitty dump they live on.  What little money comes in goes to booze. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does the family survive? WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know.  Food banks, welfare, church charity.  They scrape by. MITCHELL looks at RISA, who has remained silent. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Doreen? RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She...she was a friend of mine. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When? RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At school.  She fell for Kyle just before we graduated.  Got pregnant, and...went to live in a trailer up on a woodlot Kyle's dad used to own. Kyle started spending more and more time at the Spread Eagle... MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the local bar? RISA (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...coming home drunk and I guess feeling trapped by his life and blaming her for that...and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RISA hesitates. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking it out on her. MITCHELL stops taking notes, and looks at the WALKERS. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He beat her? RISA nods.  MITCHELL crosses the LAMBSTONS off of his lis He looks up at RISA and WENDELL. MITCHELL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, to do this right, to actually have a chance at winning - of getting some money to compensate you for the loss of your boy - we need folks like you.  Sensitive, loving parents.  People with no criminal background or history of trouble in town.  Do you understand? The WALKERS nod. MITCHELL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, of all these parents you've told me about whose kids were killed, who would you consider to be good upstanding neighbors? RISA stares hard at MITCHELL. RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People who will help our cause. Pause. RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there's the Hamiltons.  Joe and Shelly Hamilton. WENDELL (caustically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, right. Beat.  MITCHELL looks at WENDELL, waiting for an explanation. WENDELL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, everyone knows Joey steals antiques from summer cottages. Resells them to dealers in the city. He's been doing that for years. MITCHELL regards WENDELL with a slight smile of admiratio MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great, Wendell.  That's the sort of thing I need to know.  So it doesn't come back to haunt our case later on. RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's the Prescots... WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sonofabitch owes thousands to the bank and half the businesses in town.  He's about to lose his house and car. RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Charlene... WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlene's over at the Spread Eagle every other night.  Sleeps with whatever she can get her hands on. She'll go down for a pat on the head and a fistful of peanuts. MITCHELL is taking notes. WENDELL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't even think of the Bilodeaus or the Atwaters.  They're all inbred. RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ottos. Pause.  MITCHELL waits.  No response from WENDELL. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about the Ottos. RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanda and Hartley.  They lost Bear. He was their adopted son.  A beautiful boy.  Indian. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good.  Judges like adopted Indian boys.  Tell me more about the Ottos. As RISA talks, MITCHELL takes notes. RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're smart.  Been to college. They moved here from the city about a dozen years ago. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do they do? RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crafts. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crafts? RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanda does these photographic things.  That's one of her pictures on the wall. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, they probably smoke weed. RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know that. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have they ever been busted? RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. WENDELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know is what you mean. MITCHELL regards the tension between RISA and WENDELL as continues to make notes. MITCHELL'S cell phone rings.  He answers it. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'll accept the charges. MITCHELL stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MITCHELL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mind if I step outside for a moment?  It's a private call. The WALKERS nod as MITCHELL moves outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MITCHELL speaks into his cellular phone. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zoe...Zoe, where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A newscaster is giving a report on the television screen a first class airplane cabin.  The image is silent. This scene takes place two years after the accident. MITCHELL STEPHENS is playing with his headset, which does seem to be working.  He summons a STEWARDESS over. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not getting any sound. The STEWARDESS checks the headset and confirms the proble STEWARDESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll find you another pair. The STEWARDESS leaves. A young woman seated beside MITCHELL hands him her headse ALISON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can have mine. MITCHELL takes ALISON'S headset.  Their eyes lock for a moment. ALISON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, we do know each other.  I'm Alison Jones. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alison Jones. ALISON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was a friend of Zoe's.  We went to school together.  I used to come to your house. MITCHELL (pretending to remember)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. ALISON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ally.  That was my nickname. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ally.  That's right. ALISON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just fine, Ally.  What about you? ALISON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine.  Still working with my father. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what does he do again? ALISON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He used to work with you.  Until you found out he was having an affair with your wife. Pause.  MITCHELL finally remembers ALISON JONES. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ally Jones. ALISON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is Mrs. Stephens? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're...not together. ALISON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd heard that.  But she's well? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...fine. ALISON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Zoe?  How's Zoe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.  The STEWARDESS comes back with a new headset.  Sh notices the set that ALISON has given him. STEWARDESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you've beaten me to it. The STEWARDESS hands the headset to ALISON. STEWARDESS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. The camera has remained fixed on MITCHELL'S face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WANDA and HARTLEY OTTO are waiting for the school bus wit their adopted son BEAR. The bus arrives, and the door opens to reveal DOLORES DRISCOLL, who is driving. DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Wanda.  Hi, Hartley. WANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Dolores. DOLORES watches as WANDA and HARTLEY OTTO affectionately goodbye to their boy.  WANDA gives BEAR a photograph, whi has strong psychedelic influences.  BEAR shows it proudly DOLORES. WANDA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think? DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's certainly what you'd call interesting. WANDA (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hate it. DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say that. WANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could wrap it up.  Protect the other kids. DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll just strap it on the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's for the school bazaar. DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's bizarre alright.  C'mon Bear.  Let's get you out of here. WANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Away from your crazy Mom. DOLORES (voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ottos always waited for the bus with Bear.  They were the only parents who did that, together like that.  I guess they're what you might call hippies. MITCHELL (voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean by that, Mrs. Driscoll?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOLORES and MITCHELL are in the modest livingroom of DOLORES'S house.  The conversation continues from the previous voice over. In the corner of the room sits ABBOTT, DOLORES'S husband. ABBOTT has suffered a massive stroke, and seems to be completely paralyzed.  His presence, however, is intense powerful. MITCHELL frequently looks over to ABBOTT during his conversations with DOLORES.  ABBOTT is always watching hi like a hawk, making MITCHELL uneasy. DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolores.  No one calls me 'Mrs. Driscoll'. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean by that, Dolores? DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About the Ottos? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  What do you mean by 'hippies'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, the way they look.  Their hair and clothing... MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do they have any reputation for drugs? DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, nothing like that.  The Ottos are what I'd call model citizens. They're regular at town meetings. They give their opinions  in a respectful way.  They always help out at various fund-raising bazaars in town , though they aren't church goers. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they loved Bear. DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes.  Like I said, they always came out together to see him off to school.  It's like he was their little treasure.  He was such a beautiful boy.  That's a picture of him on the wall there, behind Abbott. MITCHELL turns around to find the picture of BEAR. It is right behind ABBOTT'S head, so MITCHELL has to divi his attention between the cute PHOTOGRAPH of BEAR clutchi a prize rabbit at last year's county fair, and ABBOTT'S glaring eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PHOTOGRAPHS of various children with their pets.  Som have ribbons. DOLORES (CONT'D) (voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are all from the fair last year.  Abbott and me were judges at the pet show. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For rabbits? DOLORES (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abbott used to breed them 'til he had the stroke.  Bear won first prize.  Just look at the smile on his face. DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was one of those children that bring out the best in people.  He would have been a wonderful man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MITCHELL as he stares at the photo of BEAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera is outside the bus, looking at BEAR as he finishes waving to his parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEAR'S P.O.V. of WANDA and HARTLEY disappearing as the bu pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera moves inside the crowded bus, peering at the childrens' activity as they play with each other in the b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JESSICA and MASON ANSEL are seated at the back of the bus looking out the rear window, waving at someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JESSICA and MASON are seen waving at... BILLY ANSEL, driving behind them in his pick up truck.  H waves back at his children. DOLORES (voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy Ansel started honking at us up around Upper Hat Creek.  He always started to do that when he caught up to the bus.  He'd wave at his kids, Jessica and Mason, who always sat at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the back.  Normally, he followed us the whole distance over the ridge towards the school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conversation between MITCHELL and DOLORES continues f the previous scene. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Billy was driving behind the bus at the time of the accident? DOLORES nods.  Her expression is distant. DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy loved to see his kids in the bus.  They always sat in the back, so they could wave to each other. It comforted him. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From what? DOLORES (confused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From what? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he have any particular problems that you knew of?  Financial pressures...run-ins with the law... DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, nothing like that.  Billy's wife, Lydia, died of cancer a few years ago.  He took over raising the children by himself.  It was obvious how much he missed Lydia. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You talked about it? DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw it on his face. Pause.  DOLORES stares at MITCHELL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the windshield, the camera fixes on BILLY'S face he stares at his children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the cab of his pick up, BILLY dials a number on hi cell phone.  He continues to wave at his children as he speaks into the phone. BILLY (into the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi...Can you talk?  I'm on my way to work...I'm waving at them now...What's that noise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RISA is on a cordless phone.  She has just finished clean a room.  WENDELL is hammering in the background. RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendell's working on the roof.  He thinks he's fixing a leak.  As far as I'm concerned he's just punching in a few new holes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY smiles as he continues the conversation. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicole's coming over to look after the kids tonight.  She'll be there around six. RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, that's too early. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said she's got to be home by nine. RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you make it later? BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'll be waiting in the room. You get over as soon as you can. Okay? RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus and the pick-up are travelling through a beautifu mountain pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MITCHELL continues his conversation with ALISON as they e dinner. ALISON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad to hear that Zoe's okay. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you still in touch? ALISON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really.  The last time I saw her was at that clinic.  That was a long time ago. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one? ALISON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which clinic? ALISON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't remember the name.  It was near a beach. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunnyridge.  That was a long time ago. Beat.  ALISON proceeds cautiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALISON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So there were others? MITCHELL (as he eats)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other clinics?  Oh sure.  Clinics, half-way houses, treatment centers, detox units... ALISON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then...when did she get better? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't. ALISON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you said... MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where I'm going.  To see her. ALISON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's in trouble? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you find there's something strange about this meat? ALISON stares at her plate.  MITCHELL summons the STEWARDESS. STEWARDESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some more wine? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid this meat is overdone. STEWARDESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about that, Mr. Stephens. Would you like to try the fish? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? STEWARDESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poached salmon. MITCHELL considers this.  He is polite, but slightly edgy MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a cold plate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEWARDESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there shrimp on it? STEWARDESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you could pick the shrimp off, as well as anything that touches the shrimp... STEWARDESS (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure if that will leave much on the plate. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's see what we get. The STEWARDESS leaves with MITCHELL'S food.  MITCHELL get up. MITCHELL (CONT'D) (to ALISON)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you could excuse me for a moment. ALISON nods.  MITCHELL leaves.  ALISON picks at her meat undecidedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the mirror of the tiny washroom of the plane, MITCHELL washes some water on his face.  He stares at his reflecti in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MITCHELL approaches the house of HARTLEY and WANDA OTTO. gets out of his car and knocks on the door. WANDA OTTO answers.  She has been crying.  The two stare each other. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Otto, my name is Mitchell Stephens.  The Walkers told me you might be willing to talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. MITCHELL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry for coming over unannounced like this, Mrs. Otto, but the Walkers said you would understand.  I know it's an awful time, but it's important that we talk. WANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a lawyer. WANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't come here. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, let me explain.  I'll only take a moment of your time. WANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. WANDA pauses, stares at MITCHELL, then lets him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MITCHELL walks into the OTTO residence.  It is a large tw storey space divided into several smaller chambers with sheets of brightly colored cloth - tie-dyes and Indian madras - that hang from wires. On a low brick platform in the centre of the main chamber a large wood-burning stove.  A few feet from the stove, sitting on an overstuffed cushion, is HARTLEY OTTO. HARTLEY is listening to music on his headphones.  He is v stoned.  WANDA moves over, and pulls the headphones off h husband's head. WANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a guest.  What did you say your name was? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell Stephens. MITCHELL hands them a card.  HARTLEY reads it with deliberation. WANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Walkers sent him by. HARTLEY rises up.  He stares at MITCHELL.  A tense pause. HARTLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a cup of tea or something? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cup of tea would be nice. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would it be alright if I sit down for a few minutes, Mrs. Otto?  I want to talk to you. WANDA stares at MITCHELL.  No response.  MITCHELL waits a beat, then seats himself rather uncomfortably on a large pillow.  He is unsure whether to cross his legs, or fold them under his chin. MITCHELL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Walkers spoke very highly of you. WANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been retained? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. WANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their child died, and they got a lawyer. Pause.  MITCHELL assesses WANDA'S energy. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It should be said that my task is to represent the Walkers only in their anger.  Not their grief. WANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who did they get for that? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are angry, aren't you, Mrs. Otto?  That's why I'm here.  To give your anger a voice.  To be your

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: weapon against whoever caused that bus to go off the road. WANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolores? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my belief that Dolores was doing exactly what she'd been doing for years.  Besides, the school board's insurance on Dolores is minimal.  A few million at the very most.  The really deep pockets are to be found in the town, or in the company that made the bus. WANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think someone else caused the accident? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs.  Otto,  there is no such thing as an accident.  The word doesn't mean anything to me.  As far as I'm concerned, somebody somewhere made a decision to cut a corner.  Some corrupt agency or corporation accounted the cost variance between a ten-cent bolt and a million dollar out-of-court settlement.  They decided to sacrifice a few lives for the difference.  That's what's done, Mrs. Otto.  I've seen it happen so many times before. HARTLEY returns with the tea. HARTLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Dolores said she saw a dog and tried to... MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long has Dolores been driving that bus, Mr. Otto?  How many times has she steered clear of danger? What went wrong that morning? MITCHELL takes the cup of tea. MITCHELL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone calculated ahead of time what it would cost to sacrifice safety.  It's the darkest, most cynical thing to imagine, but it's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: absolutely true.  And now, it's up to me to make them build that bus with an extra bolt, or add an extra yard of guard rail.  It's the only way we can ensure moral responsibility in this society.  By what I do. Pause. WANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're just the thing we need. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me? WANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that what you want us to believe?  That we're completely defenseless?  That you know what's best? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me, Mrs Otto.  Listen very carefully.  I do know what's best. As we're sitting here the town or the school board or the manufacturer of that bus are lining up a battery of their own lawyers to negotiate with people as grief-stricken as yourselves.  And this makes me very, very mad.  It's why I came all the way up here.  If everyone had done their job with integrity your son would be alive this morning and safely in school.  I promise you that I will pursue and reveal who it was that did not do their job. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is responsible for this tragedy. Then, in your name and the Walkers' name and the name of whoever decides to join us, I shall sue.  I shall sue for negligence until they bleed. Pause. WANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want that person to go to jail. For the rest of his life.  I want him to die there.  I don't want his money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MITCHELL nods sympathetically. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's unlikely that anyone will go to prison, Mrs. Otto.  But he or his company will pay in other ways.  And we must make them pay.  Not for the money or to compensate you for the loss of your son.  That can't be done.  But to protect other innocent children.  You see, I'm not just here to speak for your anger, but for the future as well. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What we're talking about is an ongoing relationship to time. Pause.  HARTLEY looks at MITCHELL'S teacup. HARTLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't ask if you wanted milk. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  A little sugar though. HARTLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've only got honey. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll...take it straight. MITCHELL maintains his eye contact with WANDA. WANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you expensive? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you agree to have me represent you in this suit, I will require no payment until after the case is won, when I will require one third of the awarded amount.  If there is no award made, then my services will cost you nothing.  It's a standard agreement. WANDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have this agreement with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's in my car. MITCHELL gets up. MITCHELL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll just be a minute.  Anyhow, you should discuss this all without me before you make any decision. MITCHELL moves to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MITCHELL leaves the house and moves to his car.  He gets inside and closes the door. Once inside, MITCHELL opens his briefcase and takes out a agreement for the OTTOS.  Something inside the briefcase catches his attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A photograph of ZOE. MITCHELL stares at this photograph. MITCHELL (voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've done everything the loving father of a drug addict is supposed to do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MITCHELL and ALISON have finished dinner.  MITCHELL is drinking a triple scotch. MITCHELL (continuing from voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I've sent her to the best hospitals, she's seen all the best doctors.  It doesn't matter.  Two weeks later she's on the street. New York, Vancouver, Pittsburgh, Toronto, L.A.  The next time I hear from her, it's a phone call scamming for money.  Money for school, or money for a new kind of therapist,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: or money for a plane ticket home. 'Oh Daddy, just let me come home...Please, Daddy, I have to see you...'  But she never comes home. I'm always at the airport, but she's never there.  Ten years of this, ten years of these lies, of imagining what happens if I don't send the money, of  kicking down doors and dragging her out of rat-infested apartments, of explaining why that couldn't be my daughter in a porn flick someone saw...well, enough rage and helplessness, and your love turns to something else. ALISON (soft)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What...does it turn to? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It turns to steaming piss. Pause.  ALISON is shocked by MITCHELL'S intensity.  He collects himself. MITCHELL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm...so sorry. ALISON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY is chasing his kids around the yard of their house. NICOLE appears, and watching BILLY play with JESSICA and MASON.  BILLY notices her, and runs up breathlessly, BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Nicole. NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Mr. Ansel.  Hi, Jessica, Mason... BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They just finished supper. NICOLE (to the kids)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children shake their heads.  NICOLE and BILLY laugh. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be back around nine. NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY is playing his electric guitar in the same garage t MITCHELL walked into at the beginning of the film. This is the gas station/repair shop/car wash that BILLY runs. BILLY checks his watch, and takes his guitar off.  He lea the garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY is walking along a path behind the hotel, making su that he is not seen.  He sneaks into Room 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY is sitting in a chair in Room 11, smoking a cigaret The room is dark.  After a while, RISA enters through the door and slips inside. RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been waiting long? BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A while. RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, do you have to smoke? Wendell can smell if someone's been smoking. BILLY gets up to put out his cigarette in the toilet.  He notices some work tools in the washroom. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's all this? RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendell put some fresh enamel on that break in the tub. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does this mean I can't take a shower? RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  It should be dry by now. BILLY nods.  He turns around, looks at RISA, and begins t unbutton her shirt.  RISA stops him, smiles, and kisses BILLY.  After a moment, she pulls away, unbuckles her bel and slips off her jeans.  She moves to the bed. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time's he coming home? RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the game's over, I guess. BILLY moves to the radio and turns it on, tuning into a hockey game.  RISA laughs.  He lowers the volume.  RISA takes off her shirt, and moves behind BILLY, kissing his neck.  BILLY closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JESSICA and MASON, BILLY'S children, are being read to sl by NICOLE.  She reads from Robert Browning's THE PIED PIP OF HAMELIN. NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Pied Piper of Hamelin. By famous Hanover city; The river Weser, deep and wide, Washes its wall on the southern side; A pleasanter spot you never spied; But, when begins my ditty... MASON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a ditty again? NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like a song. MASON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When begins my ditty, Almost five hundred years ago, To see the townsfolk suffer so From vermin, was a pity... MASON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's vermin again? NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rats! They fought the dogs and killed the cats, And bit the babies in the cradles, And ate the cheeses out of vats. And licked the soup from the cook's own ladles, Split open the kegs of salted sprats, Made nests inside men's Sunday hats, And even spoiled the women's chats, By drowning their speaking With shrieking and squeaking In fifty different sharps and flats... MASON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicole? NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. MASON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I sit beside you on the bus tomorrow? NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you usually like to sit at the back?  To wave at your Dad? MASON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to sit beside you tomorrow. NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. NICOLE covers JESSICA, and gets up to leave. MASON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicole? NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, Mason? MASON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did the Pied Piper take the children away because he was mad that the town didn't pay him? NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. MASON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if he knew magic - if he could get the kids into the mountain - why couldn't he use his pipe to make the people pay him for getting rid of the rats? NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because...he wanted to them to be punished. MASON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people in the town? NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. MASON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he was mean? NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Not mean.  Just...very angry. MASON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should I keep reading? MASON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. NICOLE smiles at MASON.  JESSICA is already asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Room 11 at the Bide-A-Wile.  RISA is naked, sitting cross legged on the bed.  BILLY has just gotten into the shower RISA stares at BILLY through the semi-transparent curtain RISA stands up and walks to the window.  She looks across the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RISA'S P.O.V. of the rain-glistened concrete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICOLE is in BILLY'S bedroom.  She has some womens' cloth laid out on the bed, and is staring at the selection of blouses and summer dresses.  The camera slowly glides to picture that BILLY has beside his bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The photograph.  It shows BILLY and his deceased wife, LYDIA. Back to NICOLE, selecting various items of LYDIA'S clothi and placing them over her body, seeing how she looks in t mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RISA'S DAYDREAM.  A montage of various events, watched fr the window in Room 11.  RISA is seen talking to BILLY on cordless phone (Scene 34), as well as going through vario activities.  Finally, RISA is seen putting her son, SEAN, into the schoolbus.  As the bus pulls away, RISA waves goodbye.  RISA turns around and walks to the camera.  She stops in front of the lens and stares into it, her expression calm and serene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Present time.  Night.  RISA is sitting on the bed, naked, her legs crossed.  She looks to the side, lost in thought BILLY is behind her, putting on his clothes. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you thinking? RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow I'm going to put Sean on the bus.  He won't want to go.  He never does.  He'll cry and want to hold on to me. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's because he misses you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's natural. RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your kids never cry. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe that's because they know I'm going to follow them.  Behind the bus. RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can look forward to that. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like we look forward to this. BILLY looks at RISA and smiles at her with affection.  He moves to the door. RISA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're leaving. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I better get back. RISA nods. RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Billy. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night. BILLY leaves.  RISA, still naked, moves to the washroom. She stares into the tub, noticing that the white enamel t WENDELL has applied has been washed away from BILLY'S shower. RISA picks up a tube of the enamel, and begins to re-appl it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICOLE shows BILLY the clothes she has chosen.  BILLY sta at the selection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure? BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It just seems...kind of weird. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicole, I'm just going to pack all this stuff and give it to the church for charity.  Don't feel bad. Unless you feel strange about wearing it. NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I mean, I remember Mrs. Ansel wearing some of this stuff, but...I don't feel funny about that.  I really liked her. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she really liked you.  She would've given you all this if she'd outgrown it, or... BILLY trails off, suddenly consumed with sadness. NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean 'outgrown it'? BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure. NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. NICOLE turns to leave, taking the clothes with her. NICOLE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Mr. Ansel. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Nicole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICOLE leaves the house and walks towards the car where h father is waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICOLE gets into the car beside her father. SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What took so long? NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. SAM stares at the bundle of clothes on NICOLE's lap. SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that? NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs.  Ansel's clothing. SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it fit? NICOLE nods, staring ahead, as SAM starts the car and dri away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAM drives up the driveway to the Burnell home.  He opens the door, and takes a blanket from the back.  NICOLE gets out as well.  The two walk towards the barn. NICOLE (voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once more he stept into the street, And to his lips again Laid his long pipe of smooth straight cane; And ere he blew three notes such sweet soft notes as yet musician's cunning Never gave the enraptured air - There was a rustling, seemed like a bustling Of merry crowds justling at pitching and hustling, Small feet were pattering, wooden shoes clattering,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little hands clapping and little tongues chattering, And, like fowls in a farm-yard when the barley is scattering, Out came the children running. All the little boys and girls, With rosy cheeks and flaxen curls, And sparkling eyes and teeth like pearls. Tripping and skipping, ran merrily after The wonderful music with shouting and laughter... Inside the barn, SAM and NICOLE are engaged in a sexual embrace.  The camera glides past them as NICOLE's voice continues to read from the poem. NICOLE (CONT'D) (voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When, lo, as they reached the mountain-side, A wondrous portal opened wide, As if a cavern was suddenly hollowed; And the Piper advanced and the children followed, And when all were in to the very last, The door in the mountain-side shut fast...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE-UP of NICOLE in the bus as it makes it's way to school.  She seems to be listening to her own voice as it reads from the poem. NICOLE (voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I say, all?  No!  One was lame, And could not dance the whole of the way; And in after years, if you would blame His sadness, he was used to say,- 'It's dull in the town since my

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: playmates left! I can't forget that I'm bereft Of all the pleasant sights they see, Which the Piper also promised me. For me led us, he said, to a joyous land, Joining the town and just at hand, Where waters gushed and fruit-trees grew, And flowers put forth a fairer hue, And everything was strange and new... On this last line, NICOLE's lips begin to move, as she repeats the line out loud to herself. NICOLE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything was strange and new.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HELICOPTER shot of the schoolbus making its way through the winter terrain.  DOLORES' voice is heard over this sweeping panoramic shot. DOLORES (voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the time I reached the bottom of Bartlett Hill Road, I had half my load, over twenty kids, aboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus comes to a stop where a couple of children in bri snow suits are waiting by the side of the road.  DOLORES opens the door and the kids climb in.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: DOLORES (voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They had walked to their places on the main road from the smaller lanes DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and private roadways that run off it.  Bright little clusters of three and four children - like berries waiting to be plucked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOLORES is continuing her conversation with MITCHELL. DOLORES (smiling to herself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the way I thought of them sometimes. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Berries. DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Like I was putting them into my big basket.  Clearing the hillside of its children. Pause.  MITCHELL stares at DOLORES, disturbed by this ima DOLORES looks back at him. DOLORES (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abbott and I used to do a lot of that in the spring. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Berry-picking. DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  The old-fashioned way. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what's that? DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With our hands. MITCHELL nods, stealing a glance ABBOTT, who stares at hi intensely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus pulls up across the road from the Bide-A-Wile Mot DOLORES watches as RISA walks her little boy, SEAN, acros the road to the bus. DOLORES (voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyhow, my next stop was across from the Bide-A-Wile, which is owned and operated by Risa and Wendell Walker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Risa walked her little boy, Sean, across the road, which was customary.  Sean had some kind of learning disability. DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was behind all the other kids his age in school and was too fragile and nervous to play sports.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOLORES continues to talk to MITCHELL, who takes notes. DOLORES (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A strange little fellow, but you couldn't help liking him.  He was close to ten but seemed more like a frightened five or six. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were his parents...attentive to him? DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mentioned that he had a learning disability. DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did his parents attend to that? DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did they give him special care? DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Walkers loved Sean.  He was their only child...the object of all their attention.  I mean, Wendell's a withdrawn sort of man.  That's his nature.  But Risa, she's still got dreams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOLORES opens the door for SEAN.  RISA is wearing a down parka over her nightgown and bathrobe and is wearing slippers. RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Dolores. DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Risa.  Aren't your feet freezing? RISA looks down at her slippers. RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess they are. SEAN gets to the landing of the bus, then turns around an looks at his mother.  He extends his hands like a baby wanting to be hugged. SEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to stay with you. Pause.  RISA stares at her son with great intensity and feeling. RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on now, Sean.  Go on. SEAN turns away and looks into the bus full of children. NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Sean.  Sit next to me. MASON is sitting beside NICOLE.  NICOLE whispers somethin to him, and he makes his way for SEAN. MASON goes to the back of the bus and sits beside his sister, JESSICA.  SEAN moves tentatively towards NICOLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back on DOLORES and RISA. DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he okay? RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Temperature? RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  He's not sick or anything. It's just one of those mornings, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOLORES continues her conversation with MITCHELL STEPHENS DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I never had 'those mornings' myself.  Not so long as I had the schoolbus to drive.  Not so long as I had my kids. DOLORES is lost in this memory, realizing she will never drive the children again.  A tear runs down her cheek. ABBOTT, sensing his wife's mood, activates his electric wheelchair and maneuvers himself towards DOLORES. MITCHELL watches as DOLORES grasps ABBOTT'S hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICOLE is seated in the bus next to SEAN.  She is staring the large speedometer on the front panel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The speedometer reads 51 miles an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JESSICA and MASON, BILLY'S children, wave at their father from the back of the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY waving back at his children.  His expression sudden changes as he sees...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From BILLY'S point of view, the schoolbus smashes through the guardrail and the snowbank.  It plummets down the embankment to the frozen-over pond. Still upright, the bus slides across the ice to the far side.  The ice lets go and the rear half of the yellow bu is swallowed at once by the freezing water.  The sound of the ice breaking is terrifying. DOLORES (voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It emerged from the blowing snow on the right side of the road.  It might have been a dog or a small deer or maybe even a lost child.  It might have been an optical illusion or a mirage.  Whatever it was, for the rest of my life I will remember that red-brown blur... An eerie silence as the camera stares at the scene of the accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera is high above the bed, looking down on a sleep family. This is the same image as from the beginning of the film. A FATHER, a MOTHER, and a THREE YEAR OLD GIRL, naked in b MITCHELL (voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time I get on one of these flights to rescue Zoe, I remember the summer we almost lost her.  She was three years old.  It happened in the morning, at this cottage we used to rent.  We were all sleeping together in bed.  It was a wonderful time in our lives.  We still thought we had a future together, the three of us.  Did you ever visit the cottage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MITCHELL is telling the story to ALISON. ALISON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I...don't think so. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I woke to the sound of Zoe's breathing.  It was laboured.  I looked over and noticed she was sweating and all swollen.  I grabbed her, rushed to the kitchen, and splashed water on her face. ALISON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know.  I was in a panic.  I guessed she'd been bitten by an insect, but there was no doctor. The nearest hospital was forty miles away, and Zoe was continuing to swell.  Klara took her in her arms and tried to breast-feed her, while I dialed the hospital.  I finally got a doctor on the line.  He sounded young, but cool.  He was confident, but there was a nervousness.  He have been an intern.  This was the first time he ever had to deal with anything like this.  He wanted to seem like he knew what he was doing, but he was just as scared as I was. ALISON stares at MITCHELL, taken by his need to chronicle and detail this irrelevant stranger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FATHER (YOUNG MITCHELL) is on the phone.  The camera is behind his head. In front of him, MOTHER (KLARA) is breast-feeding the THR YEAR OLD GIRL (ZOE). MITCHELL (voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He surmised that there was a nest of baby black widow spiders in the mattress.  He told me they had to be babies, or else with Zoe's body

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: weight she'd be dead.  He told me I had to rush her to the hospital.  He was alone.  There was no ambulance available.  'Now you listen', he said, 'There's a good chance you can get her to me before her throat closes, but the important thing is to keep her calm.'  He asked if there was one of us she was more relaxed with than the other.  I said, 'Yes, with me.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MITCHELL continues telling the story to ALISON. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which was true enough, especially at that moment.  Klara was wild-eyed with fear, and her fear was contagious.  I was a better actor than she was, that's all.  Zoe loved us equally then.  Just like she hates us both equally now. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor told me that I should hold her in my lap, and let Klara drive to the hospital.  He asked me to bring a small, sharp knife.  It had to be clean.  There was no time to sterilize properly.  He explained how to perform an emergency tracheotomy.  How to cut into my daughter's throat and windpipe without causing her to bleed to death.  He told me there'd be a lot of blood.  I said I didn't think I could do it.  'If her throat closes up and stops her breathing, you'll have to, Mr. Stephens.  You'll have a minute and a half, two minutes maybe, and she'll probably be unconscious when you do it.  But if you can keep her calm and relaxed, if you don't let her little heart beat too fast and spread the poison around, then you might just make it over here first.  You get going now', and he hung up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little girl staring innocently into the lens as a male voice sings a lullaby to her. It is now recognized as MITCHELL'S voice, singing to his daughter as she is driven to the hospital. MITCHELL (voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was an unforgettable drive.  I was divided into two people.  One part of me was Daddy, singing a lullaby to his little girl. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other part was a surgeon, ready to cut into her throat.  I waited for the second that Zoe's breath stopped to make that incision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALISON stares at MITCHELL as he finishes his story. ALISON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.  We made it to the hospital.  I didn't have to go as far as I was prepared to.  But I was prepared to go all the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An open sky.  BILLY ANSEL'S face appears in the frame, looking down at the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera is staring down at BILLY as he identifies the bodies of his two children. The camera is at a great height. As BILLY walks away, the camera floats down, slowly movin on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY's P.O.V. of his wife, LYDIA, tugging a sled through the snow.  JESSICA and MASON are on either side of her. The three figures are seen from behind, trudging their wa through the winter landscape. This image has a ghostly quality to it.  It is filmed in slow motion. Suddenly, a snowball enters the frame and hits LYDIA on t back of the head.  She turns around, laughing into the camera.

dialogues.speaker: EXTREME-CLOSE-UP
dialogues.text: BILLY in his chair in Room 11 of the Bide-A-Wile.  He is alone, smoking a cigarette.  A slight faraway smile on hi lips. After a moment, the door opens.  It is RISA. They stare at each other.  Silence. RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you'd be here. RISA sits on the bed.  Pause. RISA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to the funeral? Pause. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stopped by the station a while ago.  I stared at the bus.  I could almost hear the kids inside.  There was a lawyer there.  He told me he'd gotten you signed up.  Is that true? RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something made this happen, Billy. Mr. Stephens is going to find out what it was. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?  It was an accident. RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Stephens says that someone didn't put a right bolt in the bus... BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Risa, I serviced that bus.  At the garage.  There's nothing wrong with it. RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...or that the guardrail wasn't strong enough. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You believe that? RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I have to. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I don't. BILLY gets up to leave. RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it true that you gave Nicole one of Lydia's dresses?  That she was wearing it when the bus crashed? BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. RISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you do that, Billy? BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think that caused the accident, Risa?  That it brought bad luck? Christ, it sounds to me you're looking for a witch doctor, not a lawyer.  Or maybe they're the same thing. RISA is crying.  BILLY opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I'm going to miss? More than making love?  It's the nights you couldn't get away from Wendell.  It's the nights I'd sit in that chair for an hour.  Smoking cigarettes and remembering my life before... BILLY stares at RISA painfully, then leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MITCHELL is videotaping the bus with a portable camcorder The bus is badly damaged, though essentially intact.  Mos of the windows in the rear have gone.  There is a ghostly quality to this image, as though the video light is searching through the remains of an ancient shipwreck. MITCHELL turns off the camcorder and stands in the silent night, absorbing the disturbing energy of the bus.  He he a truck approaching the garage from the distance.  It's BILLY ANSEL.  MITCHELL retreats to his parked car as BILL stops his truck in front of the bus and steps out of the truck. BILLY leaves his headlights on, and they cast dark shadow over the inside passenger seats.  BILLY stares at the bus long time.  MITCHELL approaches him. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here about your children, Mr. Ansel. BILLY takes a moment, then turns around to face MITCHELL. The two men stare at each other. MITCHELL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is... BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister, I don't want to know your name. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can help you. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not unless you can raise the dead. MITCHELL hands BILLY a card. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here.  You may change your mind. BILLY looks at the card. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Mitchell Stephens, Esquire, would you be likely to sue me if I was to beat you right now?  Beat you so bad that you pissed blood and couldn't walk for a month.  Because that's what I'm about to do. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Mr. Ansel.  I wouldn't sue you. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave us alone, Stephens.  Leave the people of this town alone.  You can't help. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can help each other.  Several people have agreed to let me represent them in a negligence suit. Your case as an individual will be stronger if I'm allowed to represent you together as a group. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Case? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Walkers have agreed.  The Ottos. Nicole Burnell's parents.  It's important to initiate proceedings right away.  Things get covered up. People lie.  That's why we have to begin our investigation quickly. Before the evidence disappears. That's why I'm out here tonight. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know Risa and Wendell Walker. They wouldn't hire a goddamned lawyer.  And the Ottos wouldn't deal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: with you.  We're not country bumpkins you can put a big city hustle on.  You're trying to use us. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're angry, Mr. Ansel.  You owe it to yourself to feel that way.  All I'm saying is let me direct your rage. BILLY stares at MITCHELL with a cold intensity.  The cell phone in MITCHELL'S car begins to ring. MITCHELL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my daughter.  Or it may be the police to tell me that they've found her dead.  She's a drug addict. BILLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you telling me this? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you this because... we've all lost our children, Mr. Ansel. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're dead to us.  They kill each other in the streets.  They wander comatose in shopping malls.  They're paralyzed in front of televisions. Something terrible has happened that's taken our children away. It's too late.  They're gone. The phone continues to ring, as BILLY stares at MITCHELL. MITCHELL turns to look at the ringing phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MITCHELL is getting ready to leave.  DOLORES is still grasping onto ABBOTT'S hand. DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a question for you, Mr. Stephens. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that, Dolores?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you that I was doing fifty miles an hour when the accident happened.  That's how I remembered it.  But the truth is, I might have been doing sixty.  Or sixty five. And if that's true, that I was over the limit when the bus went over, what would happen then? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would complicate things. DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I'd be to blame, right? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy Ansel will insist that you were driving fifty-one miles an hour.  Just like you've done every morning for the past fifteen years. DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows that?  Billy? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  He does. DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy said that? MITCHELL nods. DOLORES (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've talked to Billy? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did. DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Billy told you that he'll tell that to... MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs.  Driscoll, if Billy Ansel does not volunteer to say so in court, I will subpoena him and oblige him to testify to that effect. Pause.  MITCHELL plans his next step. MITCHELL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But in order to do that, you must let me bring a suit in your name

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: charging negligent infliction of emotional harm.  That's what I'm now asking you to consider. Pause.  DOLORES is lost. MITCHELL (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's clear to me and other people that you have suffered significantly from this event. DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What other people? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me? DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's been talking to you about what I'm feeling?  Who should care about what I'm feeling? MITCHELL stares at DOLORES. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolores, people have to know that you've suffered too. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they won't understand until you let me clear your name - your good name - once and for all.  Will you let me do that?  Will you let me do my duty? Suddenly, ABBOTT says something.  He twists his face arou his mouth, purses his lips on the left side and emits a string of broken syllables and sounds.  After this outbur DOLORES looks at MITCHELL, a comforted smile on her face. DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard what Abbott said? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything you didn't understand? MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There might have been a word or two that slipped by.  Maybe you could clarify it for me, just to be absolutely sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abbott said that the true jury of a person's peers is the people of her town.  Only they, the people who have known her all her life, and not twelve strangers, can decide her guilt or innocence.  And if I have committed a crime, then it's a crime against them, so they are the ones who must decide my punishment. MITCHELL stares at ABBOTT, who stares back. MITCHELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what he said, is it? DOLORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Abbot understands these things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MITCHELL leaves the DRISCOLL house, watched by DOLORES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICOLE BURNELL is in bed.  A doctor, DR. ROBESON, is touching her forehead.  NICOLE'S family (SAM, her mother MARY, and her little sister JENNY) DR. ROBESON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mind is kind. The camera fixes on NICOLE'S expression as she stares ahe NICOLE (voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say I'm lucky because I can't remember the accident. SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't even try to remember. MARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just think about getting well, Nicole, that's all. The camera is always fixed on NICOLE'S face when her voic over is heard. NICOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know I'm as well as I ever can be again.  So shut up, Mom.  To stay like this, to live like a slug, I'm going to have to work like someone trying to get into the Olympics. SAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
